Award.AbstractNarration: The Colorado School of Mines proposes a project to develop CONNECT (Creating Open Networks aNd Expanding Connections with Technology), a tool that provides networking assistance for attendees of conferences aimed at broadening participation. Attendees at such conferences as the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing, the Richard Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing, and the Colorado Celebration of Women in Computing, for example, consistently state that networking is an extremely valuable component of the conference. Professional networking is particularly important to underrepresented populations, as barriers to participation include a lack of mentors and the feeling of isolation that one doesn't belong. CONNECT uses technology to help BPC conference attendees develop a support network at the conference and, more importantly, sustain those connections after the conference ends. With CONNECT, attendees of a conference set networking goals prior to the event. Then, when two (or more) people want to CONNECT and exchange contact information, conference badges are scanned. CONNECT attendees also receive networking tips, a daily progress email that details which of their networking goals are being met, and suggestions on the types of people to try and meet the next day. At the end of the conference, contact information of the connections made by an attendee is shared. Feedback from an initial pilot of the system will be used to significantly improve upon the CONNECT system, adding, for example, the development of stationary CONNECT stations that do not require personnel to oversee, the ability to make a connection by transmitting a text message from a cell phone, which avoids the need to scan badges, the integration of connections with other social network systems, a face-to-face mentoring opportunity at the conference venue, a networking game component that can be used as an icebreaker, and the facilitation of forming BPC communities of individuals that share common interests. The CONNECT system will be deployed and evaluated at several different types of BPC conferences and meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the primary goals of Broadening Participation in Computing (BPC) conferences, such as the annual CRA-W Grad Cohort conference, are to recruit and retain diverse students in computing. These conferences bring students into contact with a large, national community of under-represented computer scientists and engage them as members in the community in a sustained way. Professional networking is a significant part of a conference that gives attendees (especially the student attendees) the opportunity to connect with people similar to them and/or working in their areas of interest.

This project funded the development of the CONNECT intervention system, which allows conference attendees to set networking goals, provides strategies on how to achieve those goals, and encourages attendees to meet their goals. For example, CONNECT motivates members of the BPC population to make relevant connections at the conference through matching people with?similar interests, assisting students and junior professionals to meet a new mentor, and providing those who participated in CONNECT with contact information of other attendees, if desired by both parties. ?Effective networking is a skill that can be cultivated, and CONNECT assists conference attendees to obtain this skill. The CONNECT system consists of a website, mobile applications (both iPhone and Android), and a backend system.  

We survey users of CONNECT after each deployment to help us understand how the CONNECT tool served the networking needs of attendees. Our surveys ask CONNECT users to provide data on how well CONNECT 1) helped the user understand the value of networking, 2) increased the user’s knowledge of how to network, and 3) whether the user felt comfortable using CONNECT to network with other conference attendees. We have found that CONNECT has met its goal through these surveys. For example, a majority of survey respondents for Grad Cohort 2015 used the CONNECT system and indicated they were satisfied or very satisfied with the use of CONNECT at the conference. One attendee wrote: “I’ve met some people at lunch or during some sessions, and would like to have further contact, but I only knew them by name or their university at that time and don’t have enough time to get their contact. But after that I can search their information on CONNECT and keep in touch with them. It’s awesome!” Another Grad Cohort 2015 attendee wrote: “My research field is computational geometry. There were very few people whose research interest was same as mine. I used CONNECT to find them and by message system through CONNECT I met them in lunch table.”

CONNECT was also expanded to create a networking tool for a local community. Professional networking is also important for computing students at universities; students need to be trained to understand the importance of networking, and should be given opportunities to develop their networking skills in their academic environments. CS CONNECT supports networking among students and professors within CS at the Colorado School of Mines. Several members of the computing community use CS CONNECT each semester. To illustrate, (1) 66 students used the Field Session module of CS CONNECT in Spring 2015 to select a team for this 6-week project based course and (2) 52 students (13 teams) in CSCI 306 (Software Engineering) submitted their final projects via CS CONNECT, and allowed other students to view and comment on these final projects. The main CS CCONNECT web page is at: connect.mines.edu. Anyone can visit the login page, but login credentials are required to visit the rest of the site.
